canonical_title: UPS Cargo Plane Crashes in Louisville, Kentucky, Killing at Least 12, Sparking National Investigation

members.title: UPS Cargo Plane Crashes in Louisville, Kentucky, Killing at Least 12
key_points: A UPS cargo plane experienced a catastrophic crash during takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 4, 2025, killing at least 12 people, including a child.
The plane’s left wing caught fire and an engine detached during takeoff, leading to a crash just outside the airport, with a significant debris field stretching half a mile.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is leading the investigation, with early findings indicating possible engine failure due to fuel line rupture or a fuel leak igniting the engine.

members.title: UPS Cargo Plane Crashes in Louisville, Kentucky, Killing at Least 12, Sparking National Investigation

The crash killed at least 12 people, including a child, with the death toll potentially rising as search efforts continue.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the cause of the fire and engine failure, noting similarities to a 1979 American Airlines crash involving improper maintenance.

canonical_title: Venezuela’s Maduro, fearing US attack, promotes app to report suspect behavior

members.title: Venezuela’s Maduro, fearing US attack, promotes app to report suspect behavior
key_points: Venezuela’s government under President Nicolás Maduro has repurposed the VenApp, originally a utility reporting tool, into a system for citizens to report 'suspicious behavior'—including dissent or foreign threats—raising serious concerns about privacy, freedom of expression, and political repression.

The app was launched in 2022 as a hybrid messaging and utility complaint platform but has since been used to monitor and potentially suppress political opposition, especially in the context of U.S. military activity and fears of regime change.

Human rights organizations such as Venezuela Sin Filtro and Amnesty International have criticized the app for enabling social surveillance, unlawful detentions, and the militarization of public order.

canonical_title: Democrat Mikie Sherrill wins New Jersey governor’s race

members.title: Democrat Mikie Sherrill wins New Jersey governor’s race
key_points: Mikie Sherrill, a Democratic congresswoman and former Navy helicopter pilot, won the New Jersey governor’s race, becoming the first female Democratic governor in the state’s history.

Sherrill defeated Republican nominee Jack Ciattarelli, a former state assemblyman and Trump ally, in a race that ended with a double-digit margin, reversing a year of political realignment in the state.
The victory signals a repudiation of President Trump’s first year in office and reflects the Democratic Party's strength in New Jersey despite national challenges.

Controllers report declining morale due to unpaid work, mandatory overtime, and stagnant wages, with some resorting to second jobs or loans to survive financially.

members.title: US Supreme Court lets Trump administration require gender at birth be listed on passports
key_points: The US Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to require individuals' sex at birth to be listed on new passports, reversing a Biden-era policy that permitted self-selection of gender.
The decision was based on the court's assertion that displaying sex at birth is merely recording a historical fact and does not constitute differential treatment under equal protection principles.
Transgender activists and nonbinary individuals argued the policy amounts to harassment and could lead to violence due to misgendering.

canonical_title: How Johnson and Jeffries’ once collegial relationship has soured in the era of Trump and shutdown politics

members.title: How Johnson and Jeffries’ once collegial relationship has soured in the era of Trump and shutdown politics
key_points: Mike Johnson and Hakeem Jeffries once had a collegial, faith-based working relationship rooted in shared experiences on the House Judiciary Committee and mutual respect, which contributed to bipartisan governance during split government.

Their relationship soured significantly after Donald Trump’s political resurgence and the 2024 election, as Johnson increasingly aligned with Trump’s policies and priorities, leading Democrats to feel betrayed and less confident in his reliability as a dealmaker.
The 2025 government shutdown has intensified the deterioration, with both leaders engaging in public blame-shifting, personal attacks, and failure to meet in person since September 29.

canonical_title: Appeals Court Revives Trump’s Effort to Fight Hush Money Conviction in Light of Supreme Court Immunity Ruling

members.title: Appeals Court Revives Trump’s Effort to Fight Hush Money Conviction in Light of Supreme Court Immunity Ruling
key_points: The Supreme Court's immunity ruling, which protects officials from criminal prosecution for official acts, is being used by Trump to argue that prosecutors violated the rule by introducing testimony from former White House aides like Hope Hicks and Madeleine Westerhout, who spoke about Trump’s private conduct.

The New York 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals revived Trump’s effort to move his hush money conviction to federal court, but did not allow him to bypass the district judge, instead sending the case back for further review of whether he has 'good cause' and meets the threshold for federal jurisdiction.

Trump’s legal team argues that the state prosecution violates federal campaign finance laws and the Supremacy Clause, asserting that state efforts to regulate campaign finance are preempted under federal law.

Trump’s hush money conviction appeal is revived by the 2nd Circuit, citing Supreme Court immunity and federal jurisdiction claims.

- Legal team invokes federal campaign finance laws and Supremacy Clause to challenge state prosecution

Jewish New Yorkers are politically diverse, with 64% voting for Andrew Cuomo and about one-third supporting Mamdani, reflecting a split between those who prioritize domestic policies and those wary of antisemitism and anti-Zionist views.

members.title: New York’s mayor is India’s pride – and a fierce critic of the country’s leader
key_points: Zohran Mamdani, a Muslim son of Indian-origin immigrants and a naturalized US citizen, became the first South Asian mayor of New York City, making history in a city still grappling with post-9/11 Islamophobia.
Mamdani’s victory is seen as a powerful rebuke to President Donald Trump’s anti-immigration policies and represents a shift in the political representation of South Asian diasporas globally.

He is a vocal critic of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), particularly over the Citizenship Amendment Act, the revocation of Article 370 in Jammu and Kashmir, and the 2002 Gujarat riots, where he calls Modi a 'war criminal'.

canonical_title: The Florentine Diamond Resurfaces After 100 Years in Hiding

members.title: The Florentine Diamond Resurfaces After 100 Years in Hiding
key_points: The Florentine Diamond, a 137-carat pear-shaped yellow diamond with origins in the Medici family of Florence, was preserved by the Habsburgs and hidden in a Canadian bank vault for over 100 years.

The diamond was not stolen or recut — it remained intact and was passed down through the Habsburg-Lorraine family under a strict vow of secrecy initiated by Empress Zita, who requested it be kept hidden until 100 years after Charles I’s death.

The family’s decision to keep the diamond secret for 100 years reflects both a personal and historical commitment to preserving imperial heritage and protecting the family’s legacy from political and ideological threats.

key_points: Tesla shareholders approved a $1 trillion stock-based pay package for CEO Elon Musk, giving him up to 423.7 million additional shares over ten years.
The value of the package is conditional on Tesla reaching an $8.5 trillion market cap, requiring a 466% increase in stock price, which is about 70% higher than Nvidia’s current market cap.
Musk receives no salary, and the pay package is structured as a stock grant distributed in 12 equal blocks over 10 years, equivalent to earning $275 million per day.

canonical_title: 6 'Beautiful Bill' Tax Changes That Will Benefit Wealthy Americans
entities: Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 (TCJA)

members.title: 6 'Beautiful Bill' Tax Changes That Will Benefit Wealthy Americans
key_points: The 'One Big Beautiful Bill' passed in July 2025 extends and strengthens tax breaks primarily for wealthy Americans, including lower top marginal income tax rates, permanent pass-through deductions, bonus depreciation, higher SALT deductions, increased estate and gift tax exemptions, and expanded capital gains exclusions.
The top marginal income tax rate is now permanently set at 37% for incomes above $626,350 (single filer) and $751,600 (married couple filing jointly), a continuation of the 2017 TCJA changes.
Business owners benefit from a permanent 20% pass-through deduction that reduces effective tax rates on business income from 37% to 29.6%.

canonical_title: How the UPS cargo plane crashed in Louisville, what we know about victims

members.title: How the UPS cargo plane crashed in Louisville, what we know about victims
key_points: A UPS cargo plane crashed shortly after takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on Tuesday, November 5, 2025, resulting in at least 12 fatalities.
The aircraft, an MD-11 freighter bound for Honolulu, Hawaii, was carrying 144,000 litres (38,000 gallons) of fuel, which contributed to a massive fireball and secondary explosions.
The crash occurred just 1.2 miles from the airport boundary, where it veered off the runway and collided with two nearby industrial buildings: Kentucky Petroleum Recycling and Grade A Auto Parts.

canonical_title: Oldest and Biggest Maya Temple Was Built to Depict the Cosmos

members.title: Oldest and Biggest Maya Temple Was Built to Depict the Cosmos
key_points: Aguada Fénix is the oldest and largest known Maya architectural site, built 3,050 years ago in southeastern Mexico.
The site was hidden beneath forest and farmland for millennia and only revealed through LiDAR remote sensing technology.
The design of the site represents a model of the cosmos, with a central cruciform pit and cross-shaped arrangements of ritual artifacts and colored pigments (blue north, green east, yellow south).

canonical_title: Maine Rep. Jared Golden Won’t Run for Reelection, Opening a Tough Seat for Democrats in 2026

members.title: Maine Rep. Jared Golden Won’t Run for Reelection, Opening a Tough Seat for Democrats in 2026
key_points: Maine Representative Jared Golden announced he would not seek reelection in 2026, creating a competitive open seat in one of the nation’s most challenging Democratic districts.
Golden won his seat by less than 1 point in the 2024 election, while Trump carried it by about 10 points, highlighting its status as a political battleground.
Golden's decision is framed as a personal choice rooted in his desire to spend time as a husband and father, not due to electoral concerns.

members.title: Maine Rep. Jared Golden won’t run for reelection, opening a tough seat for Democrats in 2026
key_points: Jared Golden, a Democratic representative from Maine, announced he will not seek reelection in 2026, opening a competitive seat for both parties.
Golden won Maine’s 2nd District by less than 1 point in 2024, while Donald Trump carried it by about 10 points, making it one of the most politically volatile districts in the country.

Golden's decision stems from personal and political concerns, including the length of the government shutdown, political violence threats to his family, and frustration with partisan extremism within the Democratic Party.

key_points: Abigail Spanberger becomes Virginia’s first female governor, defeating Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears, who would have been the first Black female governor in U.S. history.
Mikie Sherrill becomes New Jersey’s first Democratic female governor, following in the footsteps of Republican Christine Todd Whitman, who was the state’s first female governor.
Ghazala Hashmi becomes the first Muslim American woman elected to a statewide office in the U.S., winning Virginia’s lieutenant governor race after being elected to the state Senate in 2019.

canonical_title: FAA Reduces Air Traffic by 10% Amid Government Shutdown, Citing Controller Fatigue and Staffing Shortages
entities: Air Traffic Control System Command Center

members.title: FAA Reduces Air Traffic by 10% Amid Government Shutdown, Citing Controller Fatigue and Staffing Shortages
key_points: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) implemented a 10% reduction in air traffic across 40 high-volume markets to ensure safety amid staffing shortages caused by unpaid air traffic controllers during the government shutdown.
The reduction impacts approximately 1,800 flights and up to 268,000 seats, with some airports like O'Hare International Airport potentially seeing 121 of its scheduled flights cut.
Air traffic controllers have been working unpaid since October 1, with many on six-day workweeks and mandatory overtime, leading to fatigue and voluntary resignations or job changes.

canonical_title: Supreme Court allows Trump to prohibit gender election on passports

members.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to prohibit gender election on passports
key_points: The U.S. Supreme Court upheld President Trump's policy requiring passport applicants to list their sex based on birth certificate designation, overturning a lower court order that had allowed gender identity selection (M, F, or X).

The policy, which replaced the previously available option of selecting 'X' for non-binary individuals, was challenged by a group led by Ashton Orr, who argued it constitutes transphobia and violates the Fourteenth Amendment's guarantee of equal protection.
The government claimed that the injunction would interfere with foreign policy and scientific accuracy in international communications.

key_points: The D.C. National Guard is being deployed through the end of February 2025 under a formal order from the U.S. government, continuing an emergency response initiated in August 2025.

The deployment is justified by President Donald Trump as a response to an emergency declaration and under the authority of the Secretary of War to protect federal property and functions in Washington, D.C.
The D.C. National Guard is the largest contributor, with 949 troops, followed by West Virginia with 416, and other states including Louisiana, Mississippi, Ohio, South Carolina, Georgia, and Alabama.

canonical_title: What could help – and hurt – the investigation into the Louisville UPS plane crash

members.title: What could help – and hurt – the investigation into the Louisville UPS plane crash
key_points: A UPS cargo plane crashed shortly after takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport on November 5, 2025, killing at least 12 people and causing extensive damage to nearby structures.

Over 20 officials from the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) arrived at the crash site to investigate, recovering the plane’s black boxes, which may contain vital information about the cause of the crash.

The left engine detached during takeoff, as confirmed by airport surveillance footage; investigators are examining engine condition, maintenance history, and debris location to determine if mechanical failure contributed to the crash.

canonical_title: U.S. Sends Attack Aircraft to El Salvador Amid Regional Troop Buildup

members.title: U.S. Sends Attack Aircraft to El Salvador Amid Regional Troop Buildup
key_points: The U.S. has deployed at least three military aircraft — an AC-130J Ghostrider attack plane, a Navy P-8A Poseidon reconnaissance plane, and a C-40 Clipper jet — to El Salvador’s main international airport, signaling a significant expansion of U.S. military presence in the region.

The deployment is linked to the Trump administration’s counternarcotics operations, particularly targeting drug smuggling vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean, with the Department of Defense reporting 16 lethal strikes on suspected smuggling boats.

This deployment is unprecedented as it is likely the first time a foreign country has hosted U.S. military aircraft potentially involved in strikes, highlighting the deep alliance between El Salvador’s President Nayib Bukele and the Trump administration.

members.title: A Fight Over Maps
key_points: Gerrymandering is a growing political crisis in the U.S., with states like Texas, California, Missouri, Ohio, and North Carolina actively redrawing congressional maps to favor their respective parties.

The cycle of gerrymandering could spiral into a permanent feature of American politics, where maps are redrawn before every midterm election, leading to misleading voter outcomes and eroding public trust in democracy.
Safe districts designed to favor one party make it easier for incumbents to win, reducing electoral competition and weakening democratic accountability.

The species identified is Culiseta annulata, a cold-resistant mosquito native to the Palearctic region, which does not carry disease but is considered a nuisance.
This event is likely due to climate change, particularly record-breaking summer heat and accelerated glacial melting, which have altered the environment to support mosquito survival.

The firings have created a significant backlog in immigration courts, with thousands of cases now delayed or reassigned to inexperienced judges, pushing immigrant families to wait years longer for hearings.
A disproportionate number of judges with immigrant defense experience — 44% — were targeted in the firings, compared to a smaller share of those with prior DHS experience.

canonical_title: Cheyenne and Arapaho Children Repatriated from Carlisle Indian School Cemetery After Decades of Search
topics: Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act
entities: 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Pamela Harris
Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma

members.title: Cheyenne and Arapaho Children Repatriated from Carlisle Indian School Cemetery After Decades of Search
key_points: The Carlisle Indian Industrial School was a key site in the U.S. government's campaign to erase Native American identities through forced assimilation, beginning with the enrollment of Matavito Horse and Leah Road Traveler in October 1879.

Native children were subjected to harsh conditions including forced haircuts, military-style uniforms, separation from families, and mandatory English language instruction, with many experiencing physical, emotional, and sexual abuse.
Multiple children died of diseases such as tuberculosis, meningitis, and typhoid fever, and the records often contain errors, missing data, or contradictory information.

Cheyenne and Arapaho children were repatriated from Carlisle Indian School cemetery after decades of search, revealing a site of forced assimilation and trauma.

members.title: Judge Orders White House to Use American Sign Language Interpreters at Briefings
key_points: A federal judge ordered the White House to provide live American Sign Language (ASL) interpreters at press briefings involving President Trump or press secretary Karoline Leavitt.
The decision is based on a violation of Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities in federal programs.
ASL is considered a distinct language with its own grammar and vocabulary, and closed captioning alone is insufficient for deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

Harkins committed fraud and abuse against at least 30 women across Scotland and London, using fake investment scams and holiday schemes to steal over £214,000 and threaten physical violence.

canonical_title: What has US Supreme Court said about Trump’s trade tariffs? Does it matter?
entities: Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit (Washington, DC)

members.title: What has US Supreme Court said about Trump’s trade tariffs? Does it matter?
key_points: The U.S. Supreme Court is reviewing the legality of President Donald Trump’s use of emergency powers under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose sweeping tariffs on global trade partners.

The tariffs, including those on China, Canada, Mexico, India, Syria, steel, copper, and cars, have been challenged as unconstitutional because Congress alone holds the power to regulate tariffs under the U.S. Constitution.
Small American businesses, including toy firms and wine importers, argue that the tariffs are illegal taxes and have caused significant economic harm, including layoffs and price cuts.

canonical_title: Takeaways from Trump’s rocky Supreme Court arguments over global tariffs
entities: United States Customs and Border Protection

members.title: Takeaways from Trump’s rocky Supreme Court arguments over global tariffs
key_points: The Supreme Court, particularly conservative justices like John Roberts, Amy Coney Barrett, and Brett Kavanaugh, raised serious concerns about President Donald Trump’s use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose global tariffs without explicit congressional authorization.
Chief Justice John Roberts emphasized that the 1970s IEEPA law has never been used to impose tariffs broadly, and that Congress did not authorize such broad tariff powers in the statute.
Justice Amy Coney Barrett questioned whether the phrase 'regulate importation' in IEEPA has ever been interpreted to include tariff imposition, citing historical precedent and congressional intent.

canonical_title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?

members.title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
key_points: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error during an API update to DynamoDB, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from finding server addresses.
The root cause was a DNS failure due to a flawed update affecting DynamoDB's API, leading to a cascading failure across 113 AWS services.

The outage affected major services including Snapchat, Pinterest, Apple TV, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, Venmo, Duolingo, Canva, and major news outlets like The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

members.title: Canadian court dismisses farm’s attempt to save ostrich flock despite efforts by RFK Jr.
key_points: The Canadian Supreme Court dismissed an appeal to save a flock of 330 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms in Edgewood, British Columbia, allowing the culling to proceed under CFIA's 'stamping out' policy.
The culling was ordered due to the detection of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in December 2024, with the CFIA citing the need to protect Canada's $7 billion poultry industry.
Universal Ostrich Farms claims the ostriches are being raised to study antibody production for disease-fighting research, but the CFIA has called these claims unsubstantiated.

canonical_title: The race is on to turn your body into a GLP-1 factory

members.title: The race is on to turn your body into a GLP-1 factory
key_points: GLP-1 receptor agonists like Ozempic and Wegovy have proven effective for weight loss and blood sugar control but face limitations such as high cost, side effects, and the need for lifelong use.

RenBio and Fractyl Health are pioneering gene therapies to turn the body’s own cells into GLP-1 factories, aiming to offer long-term, potentially curative, and sustainable weight management without daily injections.

RenBio’s approach uses plasmid DNA delivered via electrical pulses to muscle cells, enabling the cells to produce GLP-1 receptor agonist proteins without integrating into the genome or passing to offspring.

Shaxawan and associates operate from RKS Solicitors in Huddersfield, claiming to offer services such as setting up businesses, arranging electricity and gas, and making immigration fines go to zero through falsified documents and ghost directors.

Undercover reporting revealed that illegal cigarettes were being sold in businesses registered under the name Kardos Mateen, and that a ghost director named Bryar Mohammed Zada, a 28-year-old from Iran, has been linked to multiple illegal mini-marts.

key_points: Outback Steakhouse closed 21 restaurants in October 2025 as part of a comprehensive turnaround strategy.
Bloomin’ Brands, Outback’s parent company, will not renew leases for 22 additional locations over the next four years, reducing total U.S. locations from 750 to 670.
The company is investing $75 million over the next three years to renovate all remaining 670 locations, including brighter interiors, a redesigned bar, smaller kitchens, and expanded pickup areas.

members.title: No, You Don’t Always Have to Confront Your Feelings Right Away
key_points: Emotional regulation does not require immediate confrontation; there are strategic ways to prolong or shorten emotional responses.
Ethan Kross, a psychologist and neuroscientist, argues that avoiding emotions temporarily can be just as valuable as confronting them immediately.
Venting emotions to friends can sometimes worsen emotional distress; reframing through empathetic listening and shared experience is more effective.

key_points: The 'shirtless fan' phenomenon began as a viral act of defiance and solidarity among Oklahoma State fans after a humiliating loss, symbolizing resilience and community spirit.

The trend quickly spread across the nation, with fans at Colorado, UCLA, Utah, Clemson, Indiana, North Texas, Iowa State, Oregon, Georgia Tech, and others adopting the behavior to express joy or solidarity, even in blowout losses.
The moment was inspired by a bet between fans, with Trent Eaton initiating the act in Section 231 of T. Boone Pickens Stadium, which was later officially named 'Section 2-No-Shirty-1'.

College football fans nationwide began removing shirts on Saturdays as a defiant, celebratory gesture after a humiliating loss at Oklahoma State, spreading to teams like Colorado, UCLA, and Clemson.

members.title: AI steps in to detect the world's deadliest infectious disease
key_points: TB remains the world's deadliest infectious disease, with over 3,500 deaths daily and more than 1.2 million annual deaths.
AI-powered x-ray analysis enables rapid TB diagnosis in areas where radiologists are scarce or unavailable.
AI models are being deployed in remote settings such as nomadic populations in Nigeria and refugee camps in Chad.

canonical_title: Frank Startup Exec Sentenced in $175 Million Fraud Case Involving JPMorgan Chase

members.title: Frank Startup Exec Sentenced in $175 Million Fraud Case Involving JPMorgan Chase
key_points: Olivier Amar, a top executive at Frank, was sentenced to over five years in prison for fraud related to a $175 million acquisition by JPMorgan Chase.
Amar and founder Charlie Javice were convicted of presenting false records claiming Frank had over 4 million customers when it actually had fewer than 400,000.
The false claims were made to deceive JPMorgan Chase into believing the startup had a large user base, which would encourage the bank to proceed with the acquisition.

canonical_title: Louvre criticised for spending money on art instead of security in years before heist

members.title: Louvre criticised for spending money on art instead of security in years before heist
key_points: The Louvre was criticized for spending years on acquiring new artworks and expanding exhibition spaces, such as the New Renaissance project, while neglecting essential security and maintenance spending.
The theft of €88 million worth of jewels from the Apollo Gallery on 19 October 2024 exposed serious vulnerabilities in the museum's security infrastructure.

The Court of Auditors found that between 2018 and 2024, the Louvre spent €105.4 million on artworks and €63.5 million on exhibition spaces, compared to only €26.7 million on maintenance and €59.5 million on palace restoration.

canonical_title: What airports could reduce flights because of shutdown? See the full list

members.title: What airports could reduce flights because of shutdown? See the full list
key_points: The US government shutdown has led to a shortage of air traffic controllers, resulting in a formal plan by the FAA to reduce flights at 40 of the country's busiest airports.
Flight cuts start at 4% on Friday, increasing to 6% by 11 November, 8% by 13 November, and reaching 10% by 14 November.
The cuts affect domestic flights only; international flights are not included, though airlines may choose to cancel some international routes.

canonical_title: Federal judge extends order blocking Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland

members.title: Federal judge extends order blocking Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland
key_points: A federal judge, Karin Immergut, has extended her order blocking President Donald Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, citing a lack of legal justification for such a deployment.
The ruling is based on the finding that protest violence was isolated, sporadic, and did not meet the legal definition of a 'rebellion' or 'organized armed hostilities'.
The deployment was deemed a violation of the Tenth Amendment, which protects state sovereignty, and the federal government failed to prove that federal officers were unable to perform their duties.

digest_abridged:
A federal judge extended a block on President Trump deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, citing insufficient legal grounds for deployment due to isolated protest violence and violation of state sovereignty.

Cities like Minneapolis, Chicago, St. Louis, Buffalo, Nashville, and Atlanta will experience significant temperature drops, with some experiencing the coldest morning temperatures since spring.

At least 69 people have died in 17 known strikes against drug-smuggling vessels, with the latest occurring on the same day as the Senate vote, fueling fears of escalation into a broader conflict.

canonical_title: Trump Revives False Claim That Americans Must Show ID to Buy Groceries

members.title: Trump Revives False Claim That Americans Must Show ID to Buy Groceries
key_points: President Donald Trump has repeatedly claimed that Americans must show ID to buy groceries, a false assertion with no basis in reality.
Genuine grocery store purchases typically do not require identification, with exceptions only for alcohol, tobacco, or prescription medications.
Trump’s claim that mail-in ballots automatically result in election fraud is false; major election experts and historical reports confirm that fraud rates are extremely low and not evidence-based.

canonical_title: RSF says it agrees to ceasefire in Sudan war

key_points: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has agreed to a humanitarian ceasefire proposed by the US-led Quad mediator group (US, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, UAE), marking a significant development in the Sudan war.
The ceasefire is intended to address catastrophic humanitarian consequences and protect civilians, with a three-month humanitarian truce as a preliminary step toward a lasting political solution.
The Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) has not accepted the ceasefire and continues to demand the RSF's withdrawal from occupied areas, raising concerns about feasibility of implementation.

key_points: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) implemented a 10% reduction in air traffic across 40 high-volume markets to ensure safety due to staffing shortages caused by air traffic controllers working unpaid during the government shutdown.
The cuts affect over 44,000 daily flights, including commercial passenger, cargo, and private aircraft, with potential impacts totaling up to 1,800 flights and 268,000 seats.

The FAA and U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy took proactive steps to prevent a crisis, citing early signs of controller fatigue and staffing shortages, especially during weekends since October 1.

members.title: FAA Implements 10% Flight Reduction Amid Government Shutdown to Ensure Safety
key_points: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) implemented a 10% reduction in air traffic across 40 high-volume markets to ensure safety amid staff fatigue and unpaid work due to the government shutdown.
Air traffic controllers have been working unpaid since October 1, leading to increased fatigue, staffing shortages, and flight delays at major U.S. airports.
The FAA’s decision was proactive, based on early signs of controller fatigue and pilot-reported safety concerns, to prevent a crisis from escalating.

digest_abridged:
The FAA reduced air traffic by 10% in 40 high-volume markets to ensure safety amid staffing shortages and controller fatigue caused by unpaid work since October 1.

canonical_title: Supreme Court allows Trump to limit passport sex markers for trans and nonbinary Americans

members.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to limit passport sex markers for trans and nonbinary Americans
key_points: The Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to require U.S. passport applicants to list their sex assigned at birth, removing the option to select a gender marker that reflects self-identification, including 'X' for nonbinary or intersex individuals.
The decision is seen as a setback for transgender and nonbinary Americans, with critics arguing that it increases risks of harassment and violence due to misidentification abroad.

The ruling was based on the government's claim that displaying biological sex at birth does not constitute sex discrimination under the Equal Protection Clause, as it applies equally to all individuals.

digest_abridged:
The U.S. Supreme Court permits the Trump administration to require passport applicants to list their sex assigned at birth, eliminating self-identified gender markers like 'X'.

canonical_title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16

members.title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16
key_points: Australia will ban children under 16 from accessing several major social media platforms, including Reddit, Kick, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X, and YouTube, effective December 10, 2025.

The ban is part of a landmark online safety law passed in November 2024, with platforms given 12 months to comply and facing civil fines of up to 49.5 million AUD (US$32.1 million) for non-compliance.

ESafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant emphasized that the ban aims to protect children from harmful algorithmic designs, such as endless scrolling and opaque content loops, and will include evaluations of impacts on children’s sleep, activity, and mental health.

canonical_title: US Economy Adds 42,000 Private-Sector Jobs in October, Recovery Seen as Tepid Amid Data Gap

members.title: US Economy Adds 42,000 Private-Sector Jobs in October, Recovery Seen as Tepid Amid Data Gap
key_points: The US economy added 42,000 private-sector jobs in October, exceeding expectations of 37,500 jobs.
The largest job gains were in trade, transportation and utilities (+47,000), education and health services (+26,000), and financial activities (+11,000).
Significant job losses occurred in information (17,000), professional and business services (15,000), and leisure and hospitality (6,000).

canonical_title: Trump Administration to Reduce Traffic at 40 Airports if Shutdown Continues

members.title: Trump Administration to Reduce Air Traffic at 40 U.S. Airports if Shutdown Continues
key_points: The Trump administration, through the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), will reduce air traffic at 40 major U.S. airports if a shutdown resolution is not reached.
The drawdown will affect approximately 10% of flights, with the 'core 30' airports—including New York, Washington, DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas, Phoenix, and Seattle—being among the most impacted.

Air traffic controllers, considered essential workers, are not being paid during the shutdown, leading to significant staffing shortages—over 400 reported since the shutdown began, more than four times the previous year’s levels.

members.title: Trump Administration to Reduce Traffic at 40 Airports if Shutdown Continues

canonical_title: How Trump’s lawyer could pull off another surprise Supreme Court win for his boss

members.title: How Trump’s lawyer could pull off another surprise Supreme Court win for his boss
key_points: President Donald Trump did not attend a Supreme Court hearing on his tariffs, but his lawyer, US Solicitor General D. John Sauer, presented the case with strong rhetorical and legal arguments.
Sauer relied heavily on the 1981 Dames & Moore v. Regan case to justify the executive’s use of IEEPA to impose tariffs, arguing that it grants broad presidential discretion in foreign affairs.

Key justices, including Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, Ketanji Brown Jackson, and Amy Coney Barrett, expressed skepticism about the legitimacy of Trump’s tariff power under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).

canonical_title: Trump Officials Accused of Bullying Tactics to Kill a Climate Measure

members.title: Trump Officials Accused of Bullying Tactics to Kill a Climate Measure
key_points: The Trump administration used personal threats, visa revocations, port access denial, and financial penalties to pressure foreign nations into opposing a global shipping pollution fee.
The pressure campaign targeted smaller or economically dependent countries, especially in the Caribbean and Pacific regions, with tactics described as 'nasty,' 'personal,' and 'unprecedented'.

The global shipping fee, negotiated over years by the International Maritime Organization (IMO), would have reduced emissions from ships — a major contributor to global greenhouse gases — and was backed by 13 countries including the EU, Japan, China, and the U.S. until the Trump return to office.

canonical_title: Snap food benefits - Trump must fully fund aid program by Friday

members.title: Snap food benefits - Trump must fully fund aid program by Friday
key_points: The Trump administration was ordered by a federal judge to fully fund the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), despite initial plans to withhold payments during the government shutdown.

Judge John McConnell, appointed by President Barack Obama, ruled that withholding SNAP benefits for political reasons violates the rights of vulnerable populations, specifically 16 million children at risk of going hungry.
The government was required to pay full SNAP benefits by Friday, November 7, 2025, with any further delay deemed 'simply unacceptable'.

canonical_title: California Approves Prop 50 to Create More Democrat-Friendly Congressional Districts

members.title: California Approves Prop 50 to Create More Democrat-Friendly Congressional Districts
key_points: California voters will approve Proposition 50, allowing Gov. Gavin Newsom to override the state’s independent redistricting commission and redraw congressional maps to make five U.S. House districts more favorable for Democrats.
The measure is part of a broader Democratic strategy to counter Republican-led redistricting efforts, especially in response to President Donald Trump’s push to shift House seats to the right.
Proposition 50 has been widely supported by Democrats, who argue it is a necessary response to political gerrymandering and a way to maintain Democratic control in the U.S. House.

members.title: California to Approve Prop 50, Redistricting Push to Create More Democrat-Friendly House Districts

Proposition 50 is part of a broader Democratic push to counter Republican redistricting efforts, especially in the context of the 2026 midterms.

The main opposition party, Chadema, claims to have documented 2,000 deaths, including over 100 from its members, with allegations that over 400 bodies were discarded by police at an undisclosed location.

key_points: California voters have approved redrawing the state’s congressional map, a move Democrats hope will help them win five additional seats.

This redistricting effort is a direct response to unprecedented Republican-led redistricting initiatives, particularly under President Donald Trump, aimed at protecting Republican majorities in the House.
Redistricting is typically conducted once every decade, but in 2025, it has become a high-stakes political tactic due to the historically tight balance of power in the U.S. House.

California voters approved a new congressional map to gain five Democratic seats amid Republican-led redistricting efforts.

canonical_title: Judge in Comey case scolds prosecutors as he orders them to produce records from probe

members.title: Judge in Comey case scolds prosecutors as he orders them to produce records from probe
key_points: A federal judge ordered prosecutors to produce grand jury materials and evidence seized from Daniel Richman, a Columbia University law professor and close friend of James Comey, due to concerns that the prosecution may have prioritized indictment over investigation.

The prosecution's claim that James Comey lied to Congress by denying authorizing media leaks through Daniel Richman has been challenged by his defense attorneys, who argue the question was vague and the materials were not provided to them in a timely manner.
The case is seen as politically charged, stemming from President Donald Trump's social media post urging Attorney General Pam Bondi to prosecute Comey and other political opponents.

canonical_title: Stunning map of ancient roads will give you a good reason to think about the Roman Empire more often

members.title: Stunning map of ancient roads will give you a good reason to think about the Roman Empire more often
key_points: A new visualization tool called Itiner-e has been developed by international researchers, mapping over 100,000 kilometers (62,000 miles) of Roman roads, with the full network extending to over 300,000 kilometers (186,000 miles).
The map includes data from historical records, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, and allows researchers and the public to calculate travel times and explore ancient routes.

Despite the vast scale, only 2.7% of the roads are known with exact locations; about 90% are less precisely known and 7% are hypothesized, revealing a significant gap in our knowledge of ancient Roman infrastructure.

canonical_title: FAA to Reduce Air Traffic by 10% at Busy Airports Amid Government Shutdown

members.title: FAA to Reduce Air Traffic by 10% at Busy Airports Amid Government Shutdown
key_points: The FAA will reduce air traffic by 10% at 40 high-volume airports to maintain safety during the government shutdown.

The reduction is due to widespread staffing shortages among air traffic controllers, exacerbated by the government shutdown, which has led to many controllers working without pay and declining morale.
Affected airports include major hubs such as Dallas, Houston, Newark, N.J., and Phoenix.

members.title: FAA to Reduce Air Traffic by 10% at Busy Airports to Maintain Safety During Government Shutdown

The reductions are intended to relieve pressure on air traffic control systems before safety is compromised.
The government shutdown has led to widespread staffing shortages, with air traffic controllers working without pay and many calling in sick or taking second jobs.

canonical_title: At least 66 killed as Typhoon Kalmaegi batters the Philippines

members.title: At least 66 killed as Typhoon Kalmaegi batters the Philippines
key_points: Typhoon Kalmaegi (locally named Tino) caused at least 66 deaths in the Philippines, including six on a military helicopter that crashed during the storm.
The floods were described as unprecedented, particularly in Cebu City, where 49 of the deaths occurred and entire towns were submerged.
Over 183mm (7 inches) of rainfall fell in Cebu City in 24 hours, far exceeding the monthly average, leading to extreme flooding.

canonical_title: Deliberations to Resume Thursday in Lawsuit Filed by Virginia Teacher Shot by 6-Year-Old Student

members.title: Deliberations to Resume Thursday in Lawsuit Filed by Virginia Teacher Shot by 6-Year-Old Student
key_points: A former Virginia teacher, Abby Zwerner, filed a $40 million lawsuit against assistant principal Ebony Parker after being shot by a 6-year-old student at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News, Virginia, in January 2023.
The case centers on accountability: whether Parker, who was responsible for school safety, failed to act on concerns about the student having a gun despite warnings from staff members.

Parker's attorneys argue that a 6-year-old bringing a gun to school is unprecedented and impossible to foresee, asserting that school safety is a shared responsibility and no single person has a legal duty to protect a teacher.

members.title: The Most Striking Stats of the 2025 Election
key_points: Democratic candidates Mikie Sherrill and Abigail Spanberger both won significant margins among Latino voters, reversing Trump’s 2024 gains in that demographic.
Young men under 30 showed strong Democratic support, with Sherrill and Spanberger each winning by 17 and 14 points, respectively.
Democratic support among voters who dislike both major parties surged, with 78% and 82% voting for Spanberger and Sherrill, indicating a strong appeal among anti-Trump voters.

canonical_title: Why has Pakistan’s HPV vaccine campaign faced a backlash?

members.title: Why has Pakistan’s HPV vaccine campaign faced a backlash?
key_points: Pakistan launched its first national HPV vaccine campaign in September 2025, targeting over 13 million girls aged 9 to 14.
The campaign faced significant public resistance due to misinformation, conspiracy theories, and cultural beliefs about sexuality and vaccination.
The vaccine used is Cecolin, a single-dose HPV vaccine developed in China, containing recombinant L1 capsid proteins and no live virus or viral DNA.

members.title: Germany offers vulnerable Afghans cash to cease immigration efforts
key_points: Germany has suspended its Afghan resettlement programme for vulnerable individuals, including former German-affiliated personnel and human rights workers, due to migration concerns.

The government is offering cash payments to Afghan nationals in Pakistan to voluntarily return to Afghanistan or a third country, effectively offering a financial incentive to abandon resettlement plans.
Afghans with legally binding court orders for entry are still allowed to enter Germany under security checks, while others are excluded.

canonical_title: Nancy Pelosi, first female US House speaker, to retire from Congress

members.title: Nancy Pelosi, first female US House speaker, to retire from Congress
key_points: Nancy Pelosi, the first female Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, announced her retirement from Congress in early 2027, marking a historic end to a 38-year political career.

Pelosi served as House Speaker from 2007 to 2011 and again from 2019 to 2023, during which she led major legislative initiatives such as the Affordable Care Act and large-scale pandemic and infrastructure relief packages.
Pelosi was a key opposition figure during the Trump administration, notably tearing up his 2020 State of the Union speech, symbolizing ideological resistance to conservative policies.

canonical_title: Supreme Court Upholds Trump's Passport Gender Marker Policy

members.title: Supreme Court Upholds Trump's Passport Gender Marker Policy
key_points: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Trump administration's policy that blocks transgender and nonbinary individuals from choosing gender markers on passports that align with their gender identity, allowing the use of sex at birth.

The decision is part of a broader pattern of the Supreme Court siding with the executive branch in emergency rulings favoring Trump’s policies, including those banning transgender service in the military.
The majority opinion cites that displaying sex at birth is no more discriminatory than displaying country of birth, as both are factual records without differential treatment.

canonical_title: How China’s Rare Earth Chokehold Could Strangle Europe’s Military Buildup
entities: European Union’s 150 billion euro loan program

members.title: How China’s Rare Earth Chokehold Could Strangle Europe’s Military Buildup
key_points: China controls approximately 98% of Europe’s rare earth imports, making Europe exceptionally vulnerable to Chinese export controls.
Rare earth elements are essential for modern military hardware such as F-35 jets, drones, submarines, and Tomahawk missiles, directly linking supply chains to defense capabilities.
China has imposed export restrictions on rare earths since April 2024, including a threat to expand those controls, creating uncertainty for European defense industries.

canonical_title: Melissa leaves 50 dead, toll expected to rise in Jamaica, Haiti

members.title: Melissa leaves 50 dead, toll expected to rise in Jamaica, Haiti
key_points: Hurricane Melissa, a Category 5 storm, caused catastrophic damage in Jamaica, Haiti, and Cuba, resulting in approximately 50 fatalities with the toll expected to rise.
More than 60% of Jamaica’s population lost power, and nearly half of its water systems remain offline, with up to 90% of structures in Black River lacking roofs.
In Haiti, at least 31 people were killed and 21 missing, with over 15,800 people still in shelters.

key_points: Zohran Mamdani's victory in the mayoral race is centered on a pledge to freeze rent for tenants in rent-stabilized apartments, addressing a core concern in New York City’s housing crisis.
New York City’s public housing system (NYCHA) faces $78 billion in needed repairs due to aging infrastructure, with residents suffering from leaks, heat outages, and structural issues.
The Elizabeth Street Garden controversy illustrates a long-standing conflict between developers and community activists over affordable housing development and community space preservation.

The explosion occurred at around 2:24 a.m. ET, with the men lighting what appeared to be Roman candle fireworks and later accessing the roof via scaffolding.
The individuals were seen wearing masks, with one wearing a gray ski mask and the other a long face mask and black hoodie; surveillance footage shows them fleeing and attempting to conceal clothing.

entities: Health care, housing, and utility costs

members.title: Spanberger and Sherrill Make History as First Female Governors in Virginia and New Jersey
key_points: Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, former U.S. Representatives, are making history by becoming the first female governors of Virginia and New Jersey, respectively.
Their victories emphasize a shift in Democratic strategy toward affordability and pragmatic governance, resonating with voters concerned about health care, housing, and utility costs.
Both women previously ran as centrist, national security-minded candidates in 2018, forming part of the 'Mod Squad' — a more centrist alternative to the progressive Squad.

members.title: Spanberger and Sherrill Make History as First Female Governors of Virginia and New Jersey
key_points: Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill, former roommates and fellow members of Congress, made history by becoming the first female governors of Virginia and New Jersey, respectively.
Their victories occurred in a pivotal moment for Democrats, as the party grapples with voter shifts toward President Donald Trump and the need for authentic, pragmatic leadership.

Both candidates campaigned aggressively on affordability issues—lowering healthcare, housing, and utility costs—which resonated with voters and helped them surpass their predecessors' 2021 vote totals.

members.title: Murder of outspoken anti-crime mayor spurs violent protests in Mexican state
key_points: The murder of Carlos Manzo, the anti-crime mayor of Uruapan, sparked violent protests in Michoacán, reflecting deep public frustration with ongoing violence and corruption.
The killings of both Manzo and Bernardo Bravo Manríquez—representing different sectors of society—highlight how organized violence has infiltrated all levels of civic life in Michoacán.
Protesters expressed anger over extortion, especially in agriculture, where farmers are forced to pay bribes to drug trafficking groups, indicating systemic exploitation.

entities: International Relief Officer Captain Dana Diamond

members.title: 3 Employees of Louisville Facility Are Missing After UPS Plane Crash That Looked Like 'Hell’s Fury,' Owner Says
key_points: A UPS cargo plane crashed into a Grade A Auto Parts facility in Louisville, Kentucky, killing at least 13 people and leaving three employees missing.
The crash, which occurred just after takeoff, resulted in a fiery explosion and destruction of the facility, described by the owner as resembling 'hell’s fury'.

Three of the missing individuals are employees of Grade A Auto Parts; two were in a building where doors melted shut and people escaped by jumping from windows, and the third was believed to be in a warehouse next door.

Three employees of Grade A Auto Parts are still missing after the crash, with two believed to have been in a burning building and one possibly in a warehouse next door.
The crash caused extensive destruction, including a fiery explosion and a half-mile-long debris field, with many victims unrecognizable.

canonical_title: Mamdani wins New York City mayoral race, in a historic victory for progressives

members.title: Mamdani wins New York City mayoral race, in a historic victory for progressives
key_points: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old Ugandan-born Democratic socialist, won the New York City mayoral race in a historic victory, becoming the city’s first Muslim, person of South Asian descent, and youngest mayor in over a century.
Mamdani defeated former Governor Andrew Cuomo (running as an Independent) and Republican Curtis Sliwa in a race that saw over two million votes cast — the highest turnout since 1969.

Mamdani’s campaign centered on progressive policies including fare-free buses, universal child care, rent stabilization, a 2030 minimum wage increase, and higher taxes on corporations and the wealthiest 1%.

members.title: North Korea accuses US of ‘wicked’ hostility over cybercrime sanctions
key_points: North Korea accuses the United States of harboring 'wicked' hostility over new cybercrime sanctions, claiming they do not reflect the true strategic situation between the two nations.

The U.S. Treasury alleges that North Korea operates state-sponsored hacking campaigns that have stolen over $3 billion in digital assets over the past three years, with illicit funds allegedly supporting its nuclear weapons program.
The sanctions target North Korean bankers and financial entities in China, Russia, and other countries, indicating a global network of financial laundering through shell companies and IT fraud.

canonical_title: Facing a spike in deadly bear attacks, Japan turns to the military and drones that bark
entities: Bear repellent sprays and box traps

members.title: Facing a spike in deadly bear attacks, Japan turns to the military and drones that bark
key_points: Japan is facing a record number of deadly bear attacks in 2025, with at least 13 deaths and over 100 injuries since April.
The surge is driven by climate change, including poor acorn harvests and warmer winters leading to delayed hibernation, pushing bears into human-populated areas.
Bear populations have increased significantly—brown bears in Hokkaido have more than doubled in 30 years, and Asiatic black bears on Honshu have increased by 1.4 times.

canonical_title: Arctic blast to bring the first taste of winter to much of the US

members.title: Arctic blast to bring the first taste of winter to much of the US
key_points: An Arctic air blast is bringing winter-like conditions to much of the U.S. starting this weekend, with temperatures dropping 10 to 20 degrees below normal east of the Rockies.
The coldest air of the season will occur on Monday, with lows at or below freezing as far south as Texas and the Appalachians.
Nashville, Tennessee, will have a high in the mid-40s on Monday, 20 degrees below normal, while Atlanta could experience its coldest morning since February.

members.title: Supreme Court to Decide If Trump Exceeded Power in Imposing Worldwide Tariffs
key_points: The Supreme Court is reviewing whether President Donald Trump exceeded constitutional authority by using emergency powers to impose worldwide tariffs without congressional approval.
The 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) has never been used to justify tariffs before, raising constitutional concerns.

Conservative justices Amy Coney Barrett and Neil Gorsuch, along with Chief Justice John Roberts, appear likely to question or oppose the administration's interpretation of presidential emergency powers.

members.title: 'Broken My Hope': Trump’s Move to Slash Refugee Arrivals Ricochets Widely
key_points: President Donald Trump's administration has drastically reduced the U.S. refugee cap to 7,500 per fiscal year, the lowest in decades, from the previous Biden-era ceiling of 125,000.
The new policy prioritizes Afrikaners from South Africa and other groups facing 'illegal or unjust discrimination,' which has been disputed by the South African government.
The decision has severely impacted refugees from Myanmar (including Rohingya), Afghanistan, and other conflict zones, with many families now facing prolonged displacement and loss of hope.

members.title: California voters OK new congressional lines, boosting Democrats ahead of midterms
key_points: California voters approved Proposition 50, a ballot measure to redraw congressional district lines in favor of Democrats, resulting in potential gains of up to five seats in the 2026 U.S. House elections.

The measure overrides the previous independent redistricting commission and replaces its maps with a Democrat-leaning map, marking a significant shift in redistricting power from an independent body to a political party.
Governor Gavin Newsom played a central role in the campaign, framing the issue as a response to Republican gerrymandering in states like Texas, Missouri, and North Carolina.

key_points: A new poll by KFF shows that 48% of Americans believe Democrats should continue refusing to approve a budget unless it includes extending Obamacare tax credits, even if it results in a government shutdown.
50% of Americans support approving a budget without the tax credits to end the shutdown quickly, accepting the risk of higher health insurance costs.
This level of support is not typical — in 2013 and 2019, public support for shutdowns over policy demands was far lower (e.g., 20% in 2013 and 28% in 2019).

members.title: Americans Still Support Democrats’ Shutdown Demands, Despite Prolonged Government Shutdown

A similar 50% of Americans believe Democrats should approve a budget without the tax credits to end the shutdown quickly, even if it increases health insurance costs.
This level of support is notable because it is significantly higher than public support for prior government shutdowns over defunding Obamacare (2013) or building a border wall (2019).

The ruling emphasized that the protests were largely sporadic and involved no organized armed rebellion, thus failing to meet the legal threshold for National Guard deployment under federal law.
The decision reaffirmed the principle of state sovereignty under the Tenth Amendment, finding that federal action infringed on Oregon’s autonomy.

canonical_title: Cheyenne and Arapaho Children Repatriated from Carlisle Indian School Cemetery
entities: 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Pamela Harris
Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma

members.title: Cheyenne and Arapaho Children Repatriated from Carlisle Indian School Cemetery
key_points: The Carlisle Indian Industrial School, established in the 1870s, was a central part of a U.S. government campaign to erase Native American cultures by removing children from their homes and forcibly assimilating them into Euro-American society.

Many students, including Matavito Horse (Cheyenne), Leah Road Traveler (Arapaho), and Elsie Davis (Cheyenne), died from diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, and meningitis — reflecting the deadly conditions and lack of medical care in the boarding schools.

Students were stripped of their cultural identities: their hair was cut, they were forced to speak English, and they were separated from families and tribal communities, effectively treating them as hostages or prisoners of assimilation.

canonical_title: Federal judge orders Trump administration to make full November SNAP payments

members.title: Federal judge orders Trump administration to make full November SNAP payments
key_points: A federal judge in Rhode Island, John McConnell, ruled that the Trump administration must make full food stamp (SNAP) payments for November, rejecting a partial funding plan that left millions at risk of hunger.
The USDA had halted SNAP benefits in November due to a government shutdown, claiming the program ran out of funding, but the judge found this action arbitrary and capricious.

members.title: Japan Deploys Military to Counter a Surge in Bear Attacks
key_points: Japan deployed military personnel to assist in managing a surge in bear attacks, especially in Akita Prefecture, where bears are foraging near homes, schools, and public areas.
Over 100 people have been injured and 12 killed since April 2025, with most attacks occurring in residential areas due to bears' access to food sources such as orchards and chestnut trees.
The bear population in Akita is estimated at over 54,000, and the region's aging, declining population has left few trained individuals to hunt bears.

canonical_title: Dick Cheney, influential Republican vice president to George W. Bush, dies
topics: Vice President of the United States

members.title: Dick Cheney, influential Republican vice president to George W. Bush, dies
key_points: Dick Cheney was the 46th U.S. Vice President under George W. Bush, wielding significant influence behind the scenes in foreign policy and national security decisions.

He was a central architect of the U.S. 'war on terror' and the 2003 invasion of Iraq, based on intelligence that later proved faulty or exaggerated, leading to widespread criticism and a 31% public approval rating post-withdrawal.

Cheney maintained a staunch conservative ideology throughout his career, but in his later years, he publicly criticized Donald Trump as a 'coward' and a threat to the republic, a rare and significant departure from his lifelong party loyalty.

key_points: The Amir Kabir Dam, one of five reservoirs supplying Tehran, holds only 14 million cubic meters of water—just 8% of its capacity—raising concerns about a two-week supply to the city.
Tehran, home to over 10 million residents, consumes approximately three million cubic meters of water daily, placing immense strain on dwindling reserves.
Iran is experiencing its worst drought in decades, with rainfall levels in Tehran province nearly unprecedented for a century.

digest_abridged:
Tehran may face complete drinking water shortage in two weeks due to critically low dam reserves amid severe drought.

canonical_title: Ex-NFL star Antonio Brown arrested on attempted murder charge in Miami shooting

members.title: Ex-NFL star Antonio Brown arrested on attempted murder charge in Miami shooting
key_points: Former NFL star Antonio Brown has been arrested on a second-degree attempted murder charge related to a shooting incident at a celebrity boxing event in Miami on May 16, 2025.
Brown, 37, was taken into custody by U.S. Marshals in Dubai and transferred to Essex County, New Jersey, where he is being held pending extradition to Miami.

According to the arrest warrant, Brown allegedly grabbed a handgun from a security staff member and fired two shots at a man he had been in a fistfight with, causing one bullet to graze the victim’s neck.

members.title: CNN exit polls: Voters’ dissatisfaction with Trump helped fuel Democratic wins in key races
key_points: Voters across Virginia, New Jersey, California, and New York City expressed significant dissatisfaction with Donald Trump’s job performance, which fueled Democratic victories in key races.
In Virginia and New Jersey, majorities of voters disapproved of Trump, with over 90% of those disapproving supporting Democratic candidates like Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill.

Economic issues — particularly cost of living, taxes, and housing — were the top concerns in all four states, with California and New Jersey showing particularly strong pessimism about the state economy.

canonical_title: White House says it will partially fund SNAP benefits after Trump threatens to withhold them until shutdown ends

members.title: White House says it will partially fund SNAP benefits after Trump threatens to withhold them until shutdown ends
key_points: The White House partially funds SNAP benefits despite President Trump's public threat to withhold them until the government shutdown ends, in compliance with a court order.
The administration taps into a $5 billion contingency fund to distribute partial benefits, with varying amounts based on household size and income levels.
Not all recipients get half their benefit; those on the maximum allotment receive half of $994, while one- and two-person households receive only $12 instead of $24.

canonical_title: US Economy Adds 42,000 Private-Sector Jobs in October, Rebounds After Two Months of Losses

members.title: US Economy Adds 42,000 Private-Sector Jobs in October, Rebounds After Two Months of Losses
key_points: The US private-sector economy added 42,000 jobs in October 2025, exceeding expectations and marking a rebound after two consecutive months of job losses.
Job gains were concentrated in trade, transportation and utilities (+47,000), education and health services (+26,000), and financial activities (+11,000).
Job losses occurred in information (–17,000), professional and business services (–15,000), and leisure and hospitality (–6,000), with the latter raising concerns about consumer spending resilience.

canonical_title: NYC's next mayor is a democratic socialist. What does that mean?

members.title: NYC's next mayor is a democratic socialist. What does that mean?
key_points: New York City has elected Zohran Mamdani as its next mayor, a democratic socialist who won with a progressive platform focused on affordability, including free bus service, frozen rents, universal childcare, and a higher minimum wage.
Mamdani is a longtime member of the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA), and the NYC-DSA played a key role in his campaign through early endorsement, volunteer recruitment, and fundraising.

Democratic socialism is not a monolithic ideology; it emphasizes government ownership of key economic sectors like energy and transportation to serve public needs, differing from traditional communism and social democracy.

United States military’s Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC)

members.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi bears down on Vietnam after 114 killed in the Philippines
key_points: Typhoon Kalmaegi, known locally as Tino, caused at least 114 deaths and 127 people missing in the Philippines, marking one of the deadliest natural disasters in the country this year.

The storm has regained strength and is now approaching Vietnam’s central regions, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) upgrading it to a Category 4 typhoon and predicting it will slam into the coast just north of Quy Nhon.

Vietnamese authorities have evacuated approximately 350,000 people in Gia Lai province and are preparing for heavy rains, damaging winds, and potential flooding that could disrupt key agricultural activities, including coffee harvests.

canonical_title: Federal Judge Extends Order Blocking Trump from Deploying National Guard Troops to Portland
entities: Supreme Court of the United States

members.title: Federal Judge Extends Order Blocking Trump from Deploying National Guard Troops to Portland
key_points: Federal Judge Karin Immergut ruled that the Trump administration exceeded its legal authority by deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, citing lack of credible evidence of organized violence or rebellion.

The deployment was found to violate the Tenth Amendment by infringing on state sovereignty, and the judge determined that protests were primarily between counter-protesters and isolated incidents, not widespread or coordinated violence.

Protests at the ICE facility involved sporadic violence, including property damage and some instances of protester-agency conflict, but no evidence of an 'organized group engaged in armed hostilities for the purpose of overtaking an instrumentality of government.'

entities: Global Initiative Against Transnational Organised Crime (Gi-Toc)

members.title: Is Mali about to fall to al-Qaeda affiliate JNIM?
key_points: JNIM, an al-Qaeda-affiliated militant group, has initiated a months-long fuel blockade of Bamako, Mali’s capital, using highway and road closures to cut off fuel supplies from neighboring countries like Senegal and Ivory Coast.
The blockade has caused severe shortages, with fuel prices soaring over 400% and leading to power cuts, school closures, and public unrest in Bamako.
JNIM is attempting to pressure the Malian military government led by Colonel Assimi Goita to negotiate by exploiting public frustration and creating a crisis that could lead to political change.

canonical_title: What Trump’s New Drug Pricing Deal Means for People With Obesity

members.title: What Trump’s New Drug Pricing Deal Means for People With Obesity
key_points: The Trump administration’s drug pricing deal lowers monthly costs for obesity medications such as orforglipron and Zepbound, with prices ranging from $149 to $449 per month depending on product and dose.

Only individuals with a BMI between 27 and 35 and specific health conditions — such as prediabetes, hypertension, kidney disease, or heart failure — are eligible for coverage under Medicare, which may expand access for previously underserved populations.

Medicaid coverage currently exists for obesity drugs under certain medical conditions, and lower drug prices may incentivize more states to expand access, especially as budget pressures have previously limited coverage.

digest_abridged:
Trump administration's obesity drug pricing deal reduces monthly costs for Medicare-eligible patients with BMI 27–35 and comorbidities, potentially expanding access via Medicaid incentives.

What changed:
- New eligibility criteria added: BMI 27–35 and comorbidities like prediabetes or heart failure.
- Price range clarified: $149–$449/month for orforglipron and Zepbound.
- Medicaid expansion potential highlighted due to cost reductions amid budget pressures.

entities: Black boxes (cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder)

members.title: Investigators Examine Key Factors in Louisville UPS Plane Crash
key_points: A UPS cargo plane crashed near Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport after a left engine detached during takeoff, resulting in at least 13 fatalities and significant damage to nearby properties.
More than two dozen NTSB officials are on-site collecting evidence, including the black boxes, the engine, and multiple engine fan blades, which are critical for determining the cause of the crash.
Investigators will analyze the crash site, which spans a half-mile and contains extensive debris, including charred metal and potential human remains, with recovery efforts ongoing.

canonical_title: Zohran Mamdani Wins New York City Mayoral Election

members.title: Zohran Mamdani Wins New York City Mayoral Election
key_points: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old democratic socialist, won the New York City mayoral election, defeating former Governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa.
Mamdani is the city's first Muslim mayor, first South Asian mayor, and one of the youngest mayors in modern history.

His campaign focused on affordability, housing, public services, and working-class empowerment, including proposals to freeze rent, offer free public buses, and provide universal childcare by taxing the wealthy.

members.title: Who Will Replace Pelosi in Congress?
key_points: Nancy Pelosi, who has held the San Francisco House seat for nearly four decades, announced her retirement after a 39-year career, creating a high-stakes race for her seat in 2026.

Scott Wiener, a state senator and moderate business-friendly Democrat, entered the race in October 2025, having waited until Pelosi's retirement became certain, and is expected to draw on strong political networks and name recognition.

Saikat Chakrabarti, a progressive tech executive and former campaign manager for Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, launched his campaign with significant financial resources and a mission to restore progressive values in the Democratic Party, despite lacking widespread name recognition.

Travelers should check flight status early, book refundable tickets, and consider travel insurance for coverage of shutdown-related disruptions.

key_points: A trillion-dollar amount is so large that it is practically incomprehensible — no real-world object or concept can be fully imagined or understood with such scale.
Elon Musk already possesses a $475 billion fortune, making the idea of him becoming a trillionaire a speculative, hyperbolic scenario.
The article uses absurd, illustrative examples (like buying every house in Hawaii or the entire Ivy League five times over) to demonstrate the scale of one trillion dollars.

members.title: What Elon Musk Could Buy with $1 Trillion
key_points: A trillion is so large it is practically incomprehensible — exemplified by the fact that spending $40 per second would take 792.5 years to exhaust a trillion-dollar amount.

Elon Musk’s current net worth is $475 billion, making him the wealthiest person in history, and the article explores how a $1 trillion wealth would still be within reach under certain market conditions.

The article uses hypothetical purchases to illustrate the absurd scale of a trillion-dollar amount, such as buying every car sold in the U.S., 333 supertall skyscrapers, 2,000 Jeff Bezos yachts, 465 Icon of the Seas cruise ships, or the entire Ivy League five times over.

canonical_title: Why are scientists rushing to study a comet from deep space?
entities: University of Hawaii’s Institute for Astronomy

members.title: Why are scientists rushing to study a comet from deep space?
key_points: 3I/ATLAS is the third known interstellar object to pass through the solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua and 2I/Borisov.
The comet was discovered in July 2025 by Larry Dennau of the ATLAS telescope team in Chile, which is funded by NASA and operated by the University of Hawaii’s Institute for Astronomy.
It passed within 29 million km of Mars in October 2025 at a speed of 310,000 km/h (193,000 mph).

members.title: Israeli Military Launches Strikes Across Southern Lebanon Against What It Says Are Hezbollah Targets
key_points: The Israeli military conducted strikes across southern Lebanon on November 6, 2025, targeting Hezbollah's Radwan Force weapons storage facilities, claiming they were reestablishing terrorist infrastructure.

Lebanese President Joseph Aoun accused Israel of violating international humanitarian law by targeting civilians and called the action a 'fully fledged crime', emphasizing the threat to Lebanese sovereignty.

The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) denounced the strikes as violations of Security Council Resolution 1701, warning that such actions endanger civilian safety and undermine diplomatic progress.

key_points: Zohran Mamdani, the newly elected mayor of New York City, becomes the first Muslim and first South Asian mayor of the city, marking a historic shift in urban American leadership.

President Donald Trump publicly expresses openness to assisting Mamdani’s administration, but insists that Mamdani must be 'respectful' of Washington, framing the relationship as conditional on political compliance.
Trump labels Mamdani a 'communist lunatic' and 'communist' despite Mamdani identifying as a democratic socialist, highlighting a broader political conflict over ideology and governance models.

canonical_title: The Colorful, Sequined Life of Judy Garland’s ‘Lucky Jacket’

members.title: The Colorful, Sequined Life of Judy Garland’s ‘Lucky Jacket’
key_points: The Judy Garland 'lucky jacket' is a symbol of both personal and cultural significance, representing a major career resurgence and a turning point in her life after illness.

The jacket’s journey reflects broader social changes, especially in LGBTQ+ history, as it passed through hands of fans, collectors, and men in love with Judy Garland, showing how personal devotion can intersect with cultural memory.

The jacket’s value has evolved from a personal heirloom to a cultural artifact, with its value increasing from $3,000 at auction in 1978 to $250,000 in 2024, reflecting its growing recognition in the arts and heritage sectors.

canonical_title: Judge hears testimony about crowded cells and overflowing toilets at Chicago-area immigration site

members.title: Judge hears testimony about crowded cells and overflowing toilets at Chicago-area immigration site
key_points: Overcrowding at the Broadview detention site in Chicago's suburbs, with up to 150 people in a single cell, led to testimony of extreme discomfort, including no beds, no hygiene supplies, and water that tasted like sewer.
Testimony from detained individuals, including Felipe Agustin Zamacona, Pablo Moreno Gonzalez, and Claudia Carolina Pereira Guevara, described conditions that raised serious human rights concerns.

The U.S. Department of Justice defended the site by stating it was never intended for long-term detention and that conditions have improved, though critics argue it functions as a de facto detention center.

canonical_title: UPS cargo plane crash devastates Louisville, where ties to the shipping giant run deep

members.title: UPS cargo plane crash devastates Louisville, where ties to the shipping giant run deep
key_points: A UPS cargo plane crashed shortly after takeoff from Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport, resulting in at least 12 deaths, with all three crew members presumed dead.

The plane was carrying over 38,000 gallons of fuel and crashed into a waste recycling facility, triggering massive explosions and a large fire that damaged multiple businesses, including an auto parts store and Kentucky Petroleum Recycling.
The crash ruptured storage tanks at the recycling facility, leading to secondary explosions and fuel leaks, though no hazardous cargo beyond fuel was onboard.

members.title: Death toll from Hurricane Melissa climbs to 49, with many still missing
key_points: Hurricane Melissa killed at least 49 people, with Haiti reporting 30 deaths and Jamaica 19, and one in the Dominican Republic before landfall.
Melissa made landfall in Jamaica as a Category 5 hurricane with sustained winds up to 295 km/h (183 mph), causing extensive damage in the western region.
The storm impacted multiple Caribbean nations, including Cuba, the Bahamas, and Bermuda, with significant flooding, wind damage, and infrastructure disruption.
